sentence: I want to talk tonight about labor productivity growth.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it focuses on labor productivity growth, which does not directly impact the decision-making process of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) regarding interest rates. Therefore, it has no implications on the monetary policy stance, being neither hawkish, dovish, nor neutral.

sentence: Labor productivity is the amount of goods and services produced per hour spent on the job.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses labor productivity, which is not directly related to the stance of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) on interest rates or monetary policy.

sentence: Increases in labor productivity--again, that's the amount of goods and services produced per hour on the job--are a fundamental factor in determining how fast the economy grows, and how fast the average standard of living grows.
reason: This sentence highlights the importance of increases in labor productivity in determining the pace of economic and standard of living growth. It is relevant to US monetary policy as it emphasizes the need for policies that promote productivity growth, which can have implications on interest rates and inflation. However, it does not directly indicate a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance on monetary policy.

sentence: And productivity growth can be influenced by government policy, about which I also want to say a few words.1Labor productivity growth varies a lot from year to year, but it is possible to discern longer historical periods with high or low productivity growth, as shown in figure 1.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the influence of government policy on productivity growth. It does not provide any indication of a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance on monetary policy.

sentence: For example, labor productivity rose at an average annual rate of 3-1/4 percent from 1948 to 1973, whereas in the period 1974 to 2016, the average growth rate of productivity was about 1.7 percent.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses historical trends in labor productivity. It does not provide any indication of whether the current policy stance is hawkish, dovish, or neutral.

sentence: That is to say that, with the important exception of the information technology (IT) boom beginning in the mid-1990s, the U.S. economy has been in a low-productivity growth period since 1974.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the productivity growth period of the US economy since 1974, without providing any direct implications on the monetary policy stance.

sentence: The record for the past five years has been particularly dismal.How much does productivity growth matter?
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it does not provide any information or implications related to the stance of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC). It discusses the past record and productivity growth, which are not directly related to monetary policy decisions.

sentence: That is a pleasure, an honor, a joy, and something of a difficulty for anyone wanting to talk about productivity and its growth in the presence of the master.The reason the rate of productivity growth matters so much is that it is a basic determinant of the rate of growth of average income per capita over long periods.2 To understand that one needs to know only the trick of calculating how long it takes for a growing economy to double.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses productivity growth and its impact on average income per capita over long periods. It does not provide any information or implications related to the FOMC's stance on monetary policy, whether hawkish, dovish, or neutral.

sentence: A good rule of thumb for calculating the time it takes labor productivity (or anything else that is growing) to double can be calculated by dividing 70 by the growth rate.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses a general rule of thumb for calculating the time it takes for labor productivity (or any growing factor) to double. It does not provide any indication of a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance on monetary policy.

sentence: When labor productivity was growing at 3-1/4 percent per year--during the 25 years from 1948 to 1973--it took 22 years for labor productivity to double.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses historical data on labor productivity growth and does not provide any indication of the current or future stance of monetary policy.

sentence: Looking again at Figure 1, in the 42 years from 1974 to 2016, when labor productivity was growing on average at a rate of 1-3/4 percent, it would have taken approximately 41 years for labor productivity to double.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses historical data on labor productivity growth. It does not provide any indication of the current or future stance of monetary policy, making it unrelated to the hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance.

sentence: There is a vast difference between the prospects facing the young in an economy where incomes per capita are doubling every 22 years and an economy in which incomes are on average doubling only every 41 years.Now, productivity statistics are imperfect in many respects--for example, capturing the value of the seemingly free apps we use on our smartphones is challenging.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the difference in prospects facing the young in economies with different rates of income doubling and highlights the imperfections in productivity statistics. It does not provide any indication of a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance on monetary policy.

sentence: And many of us who live in the modern age cannot believe that the iPhone has not fundamentally changed our lives.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the impact of the iPhone on people's lives in the modern age. It does not provide any implications or insights related to the monetary policy stance, making it unrelated to the terms hawkish, dovish, or neutral.

sentence: It has certainly changed our lives to some extent, and there is likely some underestimation of productivity growth in the official data.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the impact on individuals' lives and potential underestimation of productivity growth in official data. It does not provide any indication of a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance on monetary policy.

sentence: But to figure out whether the current degree of data bias has reduced estimated growth, we have to ask not whether there is bias, but whether the bias has increased.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it does not provide any indication of a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance. It discusses the assessment of data bias and its impact on estimated growth, which does not directly relate to monetary policy decisions.

sentence: To a first approximation, one could assume that the rate of bias is constant, and does not account for the estimated decline in productivity growth and that we should not dismiss the slowdown as an artifact of measurement difficulties3 That is the conclusion most researchers reach, but the data issue is not settled.
reason: This sentence suggests a neutral stance on US monetary policy. It acknowledges the estimated decline in productivity growth but also highlights the unresolved data issue. The statement implies that the slowdown should not be disregarded, but it does not provide a clear indication of a hawkish, dovish, or irrelevant stance.

sentence: As Bob Solow famously said, just before the increase in productivity growth of 1996-2003, "the computer is everywhere except in the growth data."
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the increase in productivity growth and the presence of computers in growth data, without providing any indication of the stance of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) towards interest rates or economic conditions.

sentence:
And there are serious researchers who have made serious arguments that we will soon be seeing more rapid growth in the productivity data.Factors determining productivity growth
Clearly, a key question for economic forecasters, and even more so for U.S. citizens, and indeed for the entire global economy, is whether we should anticipate a return of the more rapid productivity gains experienced in the IT boom and for the quarter century after the end of World War II, or should instead resign ourselves to tepid economic growth in future years.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the factors determining productivity growth and does not provide any indication of a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance on monetary policy.

sentence: And a central policy issue is whether government policies can help push the economy toward a higher-productivity regime.In this context, it is useful to think of labor productivity growth as coming from three sources, as shown in figure 2.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it does not directly address the stance of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) or its implications on interest rates. It discusses government policies and labor productivity growth, which are not directly related to the monetary policy stance of being hawkish, dovish, or neutral.

sentence: First, greater investment by firms in tangible equipment and structures, as well as "intangible" investments such as software and product designs, raise labor productivity.
reason: This sentence suggests that greater investment by firms in both tangible and intangible assets can lead to an increase in labor productivity. While it provides insight into the factors influencing economic growth, it is irrelevant to the current stance of US monetary policy.

sentence: Second, improvements in labor quality, or the capabilities of the workforce, contribute as well--through education, training, and experience.
reason: This sentence suggests that improvements in labor quality, achieved through education, training, and experience, have an impact on US monetary policy. However, it does not explicitly indicate whether this impact is hawkish, dovish, neutral, or irrelevant.

sentence: Finally, innovations yield more or better output from the same inputs--the same capital and labor--such as the introduction of the assembly line and computer-aided product design.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the concept of innovations and their impact on output, rather than addressing any specific stance or implications related to the monetary policy.

sentence: I will consider the role that policy may play through each of these channels.
reason: This sentence suggests that the speaker will assess the impact of policy on various channels. While it does not explicitly indicate a specific stance, it implies a neutral approach towards evaluating the role of policy, making it irrelevant to determine its implications on US monetary policy.

sentence: It is noteworthy that most of the recent drop in productivity is due to a lower contribution from innovation, although weaker investment has played a role as well.
reason: This sentence suggests that the recent drop in productivity is primarily attributed to a decrease in innovation, with weaker investment also playing a part. While it provides insights into the factors affecting productivity, it does not directly indicate a stance on US monetary policy. Therefore, it can be considered irrelevant to the assessment of monetary policy as it does not convey a hawkish, dovish, or neutral perspective.

sentence:
The contribution to labor productivity from labor quality has changed very little.Innovation
Our prospects for further significant technological innovations are hotly debated.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses prospects for technological innovations, which does not directly impact the decision-making process of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) regarding interest rates or monetary policy stance.

sentence: Some observers believe that we have exhausted the low-hanging fruit on the productivity tree and, in particular, that efficiency gains from the use of IT have run their course.4 Other observers argue that we can reach fruit higher on the tree with each passing year.
reason: This sentence suggests a neutral stance on US monetary policy. It acknowledges that some observers believe efficiency gains from IT have reached their limit (dovish), while others argue that there is still potential for improvement (hawkish). However, it does not provide a clear indication of the FOMC's stance, making it irrelevant for US monetary policy.

sentence: These observers believe that innovation yields better tools, such as 3-D printers and genetic sequencing equipment, which themselves enable further technological advances.5 For what it is worth, I believe the early signs of self-driving cars, the emergence of disease treatments based on genetics, and the falling costs for conventional and alternative energy production suggest that we are continuing to innovate, both in IT as well as in other parts of the economy.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the belief in innovation and its impact on technological advances in various sectors of the economy. It does not provide any indication of a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance on monetary policy.

sentence: One possibility is that we are in a productivity lull while firms reorganize to exploit the latest innovations; it took decades before the full benefits of the steam engine, electrification, and computers were seen.6One way to ensure the vigor of innovation is to support research and development (R&D), and here the recent record is mixed.
reason: This sentence suggests a neutral stance on US monetary policy. It acknowledges the possibility of a productivity lull and the importance of supporting R&D for innovation. However, it does not provide a clear indication of whether the FOMC's stance is hawkish, dovish, or irrelevant.

sentence: As shown in figure 3, R&D spending in the United States softened during the Great Recession.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses R&D spending during the Great Recession, without providing any indication of the FOMC's stance on interest rates or its implications for the economy.

sentence: R&D funded by U.S. businesses has since recovered.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the recovery of R&D funded by US businesses, which does not directly impact the monetary policy stance of being hawkish, dovish, or neutral.

sentence: However, government-funded R&D as a share of gross domestic product is at the lowest level in recent history.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses government-funded R&D and its share of gross domestic product. It does not provide any indication of a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance on monetary policy.

sentence: A great deal of the "R" in overall R&D is government funded and not tied to a specific commercial goal.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses government funding for research and development, which does not directly impact the stance of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) on interest rates or other monetary policy tools.

sentence: The applied research built on this basic research ultimately yields productivity gains far into the future.7 Consequently, the decline in government-funded R&D is disturbing.To raise productivity and economic well-being, firms must adopt innovations that emerge from R&D as quickly as possible.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the decline in government-funded R&D and the need for firms to adopt innovations. It does not provide any indication of a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance on monetary policy.

sentence: This adjustment may occur as start-ups introduce innovation to the market, as existing innovative firms expand, or as competing firms imitate the innovators.
reason: This sentence suggests that the adjustment in the market can be driven by start-ups introducing innovation, existing innovative firms expanding, or competing firms imitating the innovators. It is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it does not directly address the stance of the Federal Reserve or its impact on interest rates.

sentence: Recent research suggests that all three of these channels, which reflect the economic dynamism of businesses, have been operating sluggishly of late: New firms are not created as often as in the past, innovative firms are not hiring or investing as aggressively as they once did, and the diffusion of innovations is weak from frontier firms to trailing firms.8It is difficult to pinpoint specific policy actions that would address this decline in dynamism.
reason: This sentence suggests that the sluggish operation of the three channels impacting economic dynamism is a concern. However, it does not provide any clear indication of whether the FOMC's stance on US monetary policy would be hawkish, dovish, neutral, or irrelevant.

sentence:
Broadly speaking, however, government policymakers should carefully consider the effects of regulations and tax policy on the free flow of workers, capital, and ideas.Investment
In recent years, the contribution to labor productivity growth from investment has declined.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the contribution to labor productivity growth from investment, without directly addressing the stance of the FOMC or its implications on monetary policy.

sentence: Business fixed investment rose roughly 2-1/2 percent per year, on average, from 2004 to 2016, compared with about 5 percent from 1996 to 2003.9 Some bright spots do exist: Capital expenditure by leading IT companies--Google, Amazon, and the like--has soared since 2010, and investment in the energy sector has returned to life.
reason: This sentence suggests that business fixed investment in the US has been growing at a slower pace in recent years compared to the previous decade. However, there are some positive developments, such as increased capital expenditure by leading IT companies and a revival of investment in the energy sector. These observations are somewhat irrelevant to US monetary policy as they do not directly indicate a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance.

sentence: Nevertheless, firms as a whole seem reluctant to invest.This cautious approach to investment may in part reflect uncertainty about the policy environment.
reason: This sentence suggests a cautious approach to investment by firms, which may be influenced by uncertainty about the policy environment. It is relevant to US monetary policy as it indicates a potential impact on economic growth. However, it does not provide a clear indication of whether the stance is hawkish, dovish, or neutral.

sentence: By one measure, U.S. policy uncertainty was elevated for much of the recovery, subsided in 2013, and then rose again late last year, underpinned by uncertainty about policies associated with health care, regulation, taxes, and trade.10 Reasonable people can disagree about the right way forward on each of those issues, but mitigating the damping effect of uncertainty by providing more clarity on the future direction of government policy is highly desirable--particularly if the direction of policy itself is desirable.Government investment can be an important source of productivity growth as well.
reason: This sentence suggests that U.S. policy uncertainty has fluctuated over time, with a recent rise due to uncertainty about health care, regulation, taxes, and trade. It implies that providing more clarity on government policy direction is highly desirable to mitigate the negative impact of uncertainty. The sentence is neutral in terms of US monetary policy.

sentence: For example, the interstate highway system is credited with boosting productivity in the 1950s and 1960s.11 That highway system and many other federally supported roadways, waterways, and structures have been neglected in recent years.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the neglect of federally supported infrastructure. It does not provide any indication of a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance on monetary policy.

sentence:
Indeed, real infrastructure spending (that is, adjusting for inflation) has fallen nearly 1 percent per year since 2005.12 This area of government investment deserves more attention.Labor Quality

sentence: Such investment is a particular issue because most forecasts anticipate that the long rise in educational attainment--both for college and high school--may soon come to an end.

sentence: One area where policy may play a role is promoting educational access and readiness for groups for whom educational attainment is relatively low.Recent research has shown a substantial return to public investment in early childhood education for economically disadvantaged groups.

sentence: 13At the other end of the education process, a college degree has long been considered a worthwhile investment, and thus our society should promote access to and readiness for college among a broad range of individuals--in particular through federal support for need-based financial aid.14Lastly, I will note that ultimately the return on the human capital embodied in our workforce is closely tied to public health.
